item.title: Carrying Some Extra Pounds May Not Be Good After All
item.description: April 3, 2017 - A new study finds that people who are overweight, but not obese, have shorter life spans. It's the opposite of a 2013 study that got a lot of attention by finding a few pounds might be good for you.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 3, 2017 - A new study finds that people who are overweight, but not obese, have shorter life spans. It's the opposite of a 2013 study that got a lot of attention by finding a few pounds might be good for you. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/03/522475728/carrying-some-extra-pounds-may-not-be-good-after-all

item.title: Recall Of Some EpiPens Extends To U.S.
item.description: April 3, 2017 - Mylan is recalling some EpiPens distributed between December 2015 and July 2016, saying a potentially defective part could make them fail to activate during a life-threatening allergic reaction.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 3, 2017 - Mylan is recalling some EpiPens distributed between December 2015 and July 2016, saying a potentially defective part could make them fail to activate during a life-threatening allergic reaction. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/03/522450779/recall-of-some-epipens-extends-to-u-s

item.title: Child Deaths Drop From 14.2 Million In 1990 To 7.3 Million In 2015
item.description: April 3, 2017 - That's the encouraging news in a new report. But it also means more kids are living long enough to face a host of serious challenges to their physical and mental health.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 3, 2017 - That's the encouraging news in a new report. But it also means more kids are living long enough to face a host of serious challenges to their physical and mental health. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/03/522466048/child-deaths-drop-from-14-2-million-in-1990-to-7-3-million-in-2015

item.title: What Do Hanson And Madonna Have In Common? Hits Ideal For Saving A Life
item.description: April 3, 2017 - A New York City hospital has created a playlist of songs with the ideal tempo for CPR, although previous research suggests there is more to good chest compressions than just the right tempo.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 3, 2017 - A New York City hospital has created a playlist of songs with the ideal tempo for CPR, although previous research suggests there is more to good chest compressions than just the right tempo. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/03/521913341/what-do-hanson-and-madonna-have-in-common-hits-ideal-for-saving-a-life

item.title: 'Brave New Workers': A Burning Desire To Get A Medicinal Marijuana License
item.description: April 2, 2017 - What happens to workers when an industry fails, new technology takes off? NPR brings you stories of Americans adapting to a changing economy. This week: Leaving the black cannabis market to go legal.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 2, 2017 - What happens to workers when an industry fails, new technology takes off? NPR brings you stories of Americans adapting to a changing economy. This week: Leaving the black cannabis market to go legal. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/02/522236358/brave-new-workers-a-burning-desire-to-get-medicinal-marijuana-license

item.title: Short Film: How Water Gets From The Nile To Thirsty Refugees
item.description: April 2, 2017 - Hundreds of thousands of refugees have fled the civil war in South Sudan and resettled in Uganda. This 12-minute documentary shows the daily struggle to get water.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 2, 2017 - Hundreds of thousands of refugees have fled the civil war in South Sudan and resettled in Uganda. This 12-minute documentary shows the daily struggle to get water. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/02/522206721/short-film-how-water-gets-from-the-nile-to-thirsty-refugees

item.title: For Centuries, These Asian Recipes Have Helped New Moms Recover From Childbirth
item.description: April 2, 2017 - Postpartum soups and stews have traditionally been prepared for new moms by Asian grandmothers and aunts, the recipes passed down orally. A new cookbook seeks to preserve them before they're lost.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 2, 2017 - Postpartum soups and stews have traditionally been prepared for new moms by Asian grandmothers and aunts, the recipes passed down orally. A new cookbook seeks to preserve them before they're lost. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/02/520535846/for-centuries-these-asian-recipes-have-helped-new-moms-recover-from-childbirth

item.title: With Obamacare Here to Stay, Some States Revive Medicaid Expansion
item.description: April 2, 2017 - The failure of the Republican health care plan gave new energy to state-level efforts to expand Medicaid. We look at three states where that may happen — Kansas, Maine and Virginia.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 2, 2017 - The failure of the Republican health care plan gave new energy to state-level efforts to expand Medicaid. We look at three states where that may happen — Kansas, Maine and Virginia. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/02/522201586/with-obamacare-here-to-stay-some-states-revive-medicaid-expansion

item.title: Shot By Her Boyfriend And Now Using A Wheelchair, She Found A 'New Me'
item.description: March 31, 2017 - The State Department has honored Botswana's Malebogo Malefhe as a "woman of courage" for inspiring others to stand up to domestic abuse.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 31, 2017 - The State Department has honored Botswana's Malebogo Malefhe as a "woman of courage" for inspiring others to stand up to domestic abuse. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/03/31/521965573/shot-by-her-boyfriend-and-now-in-a-wheelchair-she-found-a-new-me

item.title: Forcing People At Vending Machines To Wait Nudges Them To Buy Healthier Snacks
item.description: March 31, 2017 - Buy an unhealthy snack and these vending machines take away 25 seconds of your life you'll never get back. Healthy fare drops instantly. Research suggests this "time tax" helps us make better choices.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 31, 2017 - Buy an unhealthy snack and these vending machines take away 25 seconds of your life you'll never get back. Healthy fare drops instantly. Research suggests this "time tax" helps us make better choices. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/31/522189753/forcing-people-at-vending-machines-to-wait-nudges-them-to-buy-healthier-snacks

item.title: Home Health Aides Fear They'll Lose Hard-Won Insurance Coverage
item.description: March 31, 2017 - Many health care aides were able to get insurance through the Affordable Care Act. But with the law's future uncertain, they don't know how their jobs or their doctor bills will be affected.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 31, 2017 - Many health care aides were able to get insurance through the Affordable Care Act. But with the law's future uncertain, they don't know how their jobs or their doctor bills will be affected. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/31/522082858/home-health-aides-fear-theyll-lose-hard-won-insurance-coverage

item.title: Why The Newly Proposed Sepsis Treatment Needs More Study
item.description: March 30, 2017 - The bodywide inflammation known as sepsis kills about 300,000 people in U.S. hospitals each year. Promising treatments have come and gone, warn skeptical doctors, who call for rigorous research.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - The bodywide inflammation known as sepsis kills about 300,000 people in U.S. hospitals each year. Promising treatments have come and gone, warn skeptical doctors, who call for rigorous research. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/30/521918863/why-the-newly-proposed-sepsis-treatment-needs-more-study

item.title: In California, Health Care Marketplace Appears To Be Thriving
item.description: March 30, 2017 - NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Peter Lee, executive director of Covered California, about how state health care exchanges will work now that the AHCA has failed in Congress.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Peter Lee, executive director of Covered California, about how state health care exchanges will work now that the AHCA has failed in Congress. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/30/522091627/in-california-health-care-marketplace-appears-to-be-thriving

item.title: In Sweden, Hundreds Of Refugee Children Gave Up On Life
item.description: March 30, 2017 - An article in this week's New Yorker writes about youngsters who fell into a comalike state in reaction to the news that their family may be deported. We interview the author.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - An article in this week's New Yorker writes about youngsters who fell into a comalike state in reaction to the news that their family may be deported. We interview the author. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/03/30/521958505/only-in-sweden-hundreds-of-refugee-children-gave-up-on-life

item.title: Why Didn't Zika Cause A Surge In Microcephaly In 2016?
item.description: March 30, 2017 - Scientists predicted that more than 1,000 babies would be born with the birth defect in Brazil last year. That never happened. Why?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - Scientists predicted that more than 1,000 babies would be born with the birth defect in Brazil last year. That never happened. Why? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/03/30/521925733/why-didnt-zika-cause-a-surge-in-microcephaly-in-2016
